questions.question: In the storage covert channel simulation, how does the sender encode information?

answers.a: By encrypting the data before transmission
answers.c: By changing the state of a shared database resource
answers.d: By sending explicit messages to the receiver

explanations.a: Incorrect. Encryption is not used in storage covert channels.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Permission changes enforce policy but do not encode data.
explanations.c: Correct. Information is encoded by altering the shared storage state.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Covert channels avoid explicit communication.

questions.question: How does the receiver decode information in the storage covert channel?

answers.b: By observing the presence or absence of a shared resource

explanations.a: Incorrect. No encrypted messages are exchanged.
explanations.b: Correct. The receiver infers data from the shared resource state.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Network traffic is not used in this simulation.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Access control rules do not carry covert data.

questions.question: What system behavior is exploited in a timing covert channel?

answers.c: Variations in execution or response time

explanations.a: Incorrect. Permission changes relate to storage covert channels.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Database records are used in storage channels.
explanations.c: Correct. Timing covert channels encode data using time variations.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Explicit communication is not covert.

questions.question: Why are timing covert channels difficult to detect in real systems?

answers.c: Timing variations can naturally occur during normal operation

explanations.a: Incorrect. No special hardware is required.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Encryption is not the cause of difficulty.
explanations.c: Correct. Natural timing variations make detection challenging.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Authentication is unrelated to timing channels.

questions.question: What role do system logs play in this experiment?

answers.c: They help infer hidden data transmission by recording system behavior

explanations.a: Incorrect. Logs do not prevent attacks.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Logs do not encrypt data.
explanations.c: Correct. Logs support analysis and inference of covert communication.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Logs do not replace access control.

questions.question: What conclusion can be drawn when a data transfer is blocked but information is still inferred?

answers.c: Information leakage can occur through unintended system behavior

explanations.a: Incorrect. Access control is still essential.
explanations.c: Correct. Covert channels demonstrate unintended information leakage.
